You need to talk to your Animal Companion/Familiar and tell it how it's supposed to perform in combat.  Summons need to be directed with the radial/voice commands.  Attack nearest and guard me, along with follow.

Lots of peeps play solo - WoG is how NWN should be; what you have experienced before is watered down easy mode.

There is no key for the Moathouse - either pick the lock or break the door down.  Chimes of Opening also do the trick, but may be hard to come by.

Generally, there are no Henchies - but there are, perhaps, some individuals that one may come across that will help out.

WoG is ALWAYS a steep learning curve, followed by meta-info.  Once one has those down pat, it's pretty much smooth sailing from there on in.

A very good tip is not to rush in and start swinging.  That will get you dirtnapped faster than anything else.  It is much smarter to move slowly and attract the attention of 1 (one) opponent with a little *plink* of a thrown object or shot, and lure it somewhere empty where it can be defeated rather easily and with little difficulty.  Rinse, repeat.

Only drop AoEs if they will wipe ALL of the effected enemies - otherwise, you will get swarmed and dirtnapped.

Solo on WoG is a learned patience game for the most part.  It will require one to really learn the ins and outs of NWN, usage of resources (like potions, scrolls, and wands, etc) and abilities/feats/spells.

THIS.IS.WOG!

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord

Looks like he's playing the old 1.69 version.  That's an older version.  However, most of the nuts and bolts are in place.  For resting, make sure you keep a bedroll in your inventory or it will double your timer.  Normally the times between rest cycles is 8 hours, which equals 16 minutes of real time (2 minutes per hour iirc).  

Also, if you see a message, "This is not a safe place to rest", that means somewhere in that area there is a safe place to rest.  As opposed to the message, "You may not rest at this time" which means you can't rest period in that area.

You animal companion will work smarter for you if you engage in a dialogue and adjust their behavior.  I typically choose an option like, "I want you to fight for me to your death" kind of option.

Note that under Sanc, your character may not be safe at all - not sure why, but that's how it is.

WoG AI is much more...robust, than the stand AI (you may have noticed already ;) ).

One of the side effects of that is how Animal Companions and Familiars (and summons to some extent) act.

So when you summon your AC (animal companion) or Fam (familiar), be sure to first speak with it before going into combat (where you most likely will not be able to speak with it because of combat) and give it directions (like what GDL has mentioned).

Summons don't have that because one often summons them in or just before combat - so one has to use the radial or voice commands.

Your bedroll will not get used up or disappear.  Food will, however, and you need food in order to rest.

If you go into the desert, you will need your canteen.  Be sure to fill it at any oasis and there are places in an oasis where you can drink.  Do so.  You will notice that you get thirsty when you get a malus to str - so drink from your canteen (or at an oasis) to remove it.

If you are level 7-8 I would go to Borderkeep or Nulb/Temple of Elemental Evil and start those questlines

It also helps to know how much you are selling things for to particular merchants
Certain merchants do not give you much in terms of gold (ie they are what is called "shrewd businessmen and businesswomen"), others are much more reasonable or even to the extent of being generous
When you get the words "Merchants reaction is favourable/unfavourable/neutral" I actually ignore this and actually calculate how much money they will actually sell things to me with items in my inventory with a good comparitor item.

A good comparitor item is one that is approximately 100gp in value, and this is what I have been taught by others on the server:

1 copper necklace
2 moonstones
10 sea gems
1 mundane heavy crossbow
5 cure light wounds potions
1 mundane scale mail / chain shirt

All are equal in value and can be used as the comparitor. I think there is more, for example, tower shield, I also think 5 caltrops (but I have to confirm) and I think there is another large weapon too but these are heavy and large to lug around, I would just carry 5 CLW pots, 1 copper necklace or 2 moonstones its simple to remember, and use this as the measure of what merchants actually pay you for what you sell.

You can use this with merchants to see how much they offer you and convert it to a percentage of the items actual value
So if a merchant offers me 50 gold for a heavy crossbow from the bandits outside hommlet, he is offering me 50% of the items actual value
Around 60+ I consider very reasonable, the highest possible I could actually get was 85
For very valuable items especially if they are light (ie the ring you mentioned) you will want maximal reward, for lesser but heavy items (ie mundane full plate or tower +1) you can sell at a 30-50% rate with a clear conscience 

Hope that helps

First of all, massive spoilers in this thread!!!!!!

Please fix.

You are ABSOLUTELY right - for the unknowing, hapless newbie, there is a dearth of magical items available in beginning shops!

As you found out, you had to travel to GH City to find a merchant who sells such (and they are mostly paltry +1 to +2 in nature).

This is mostly due to the nature of the Server - low to mid magic at the highest levels.  So think of it like this :

Levels 1 - 10 +1~+2
Levels 11 - 20 +3~+4
Levels 21 to 30 +5
Levels 30+ +5~+6

Note this is a rough estimate.

So beginning areas really should not have any magical items like +1 etc.  They have expendables like potions, wands, scrolls, instead.  This really means that being decked out in full plate with a shield makes you a pretty massive, impenetrable tank!  At least in beginning areas. Equivalent AC from other sources have the same effect.

This is why I mentioned you will look back on this later, after you get to know the Server, and see the humor in your post.  I think all newbies (me included) go through this type of "item shock" - because we have been "trained" by the OCs and other Mods, PWs, etc that have high magic environments that we come to depend on this.

Thus, we unlearn (or fail to learn) how to utilize character abilities, armor, potions, scrolls, wands, etc to their full extent, especially at beginning levels when we are really squishy (though WoG also has some rude surprises for high levels as well).

WoG cures you of this deficit.

Also, many (a lot) of PWs frown on, and even prohibit, luring individual monsters from a group away and slaying them.  On WoG, it is almost a solo players only remedy.

I will say this - when (if) you master WoG, you will find on many PWs that the challenge is gone.

These are chest which check the person or party opening the chest for weapon focuses and randomly generate an appropriate magic weapon based on the number of weapon focuses.

So if your druid had Weapon Focus: Scimitar, then a +1 scimitar would have spawned in one of the weapon focus chests (there *could* be more than one in Moathouse).
